drug.name: Glucarpidase
drug.description: Glucarpidase is the recombinant form of the Pseudomonas sp. (strain RS-16) enzyme carboxypeptidase G2 that is produced in Escherichia coli. In patients, glucarpidase inactivates methotrexate, and other antifolates, by hydrolyzing glutamate on the carboxyl terminal of these compounds. Therefore since methotrexate is eliminated enzymatically and not by the kidneys, glucarpidase is indicated in patients on methotrexate treatment who have kidney dysfunction, and are experiencing an abnormally high plasma concentration of methotrexate (>1 micromole per liter). Glucarpidase is marketed under the brand name Voraxaze®.

article.citation: Green JM: Glucarpidase to combat toxic levels of methotrexate in patients. Ther Clin Risk Manag. 2012;8:403-13. doi: 10.2147/TCRM.S30135. Epub 2012 Nov 22.
Tuffaha HW, Al Omar S: Glucarpidase for the treatment of life-threatening methotrexate overdose. Drugs Today (Barc). 2012 Nov;48(11):705-11. doi: 10.1358/dot.2012.48.11.1871575.

drug.indication: Used in patients on methotrexate treatment who have kidney dysfunction, and are experiencing an abnormally high plasma concentration of methotrexate (> 1 micromole per liter).
drug.pharmacodynamics: Glucarpidase acts as an antidote to toxic methotrexate levels by elminating methotrexate by a non-kidney route.
drug.mechanism-of-action: Glucarpidase inactivates methotrexate, and other antifolates, by hydrolyzing glutamate on the carboxyl terminal of these compounds. For methotrexate specifically, it is hydrolyzed to the inactive metabolites glutamate and 4-deoxy-4-amino-N10-methylpteroic acid (DAMPA).
drug.toxicity: Most common adverse reactions include hypotension, flushing, nausea, vomiting, headache, and paresthesia.
drug.absorption: In healthy patients not taking methotrexate, the average maximum concentration for glucarpidase was 3.3 μg/mL.
drug.half-life: In healthy patients not taking methotrexate, glucarpidase has an elimination half-life of 5.6 hours. In patients with severe renal impairment (creatinine clearance <30 mL/min), glucarpidase has an longer elimination half-life at 8.2 hours.
drug.protein-binding: Plasma protein binding was not quantified.
drug.route-of-elimination: Route of elmination was not determined.
drug.volume-of-distribution: Glucarpidase is likely limited to the plasma volume since its volume of distribution is 3.6 L.
drug.clearance: In healthy patients not taking methotrexate, glucarpidase has a clearance of 7.5 mL/min.

drug-interaction.name: Tetrahydrofolic acid
drug-interaction.description: The serum concentration of the active metabolites of Tetrahydrofolic acid can be reduced when Tetrahydrofolic acid is used in combination with Glucarpidase resulting in a loss in efficacy.

drug-interaction.name: Folic acid
drug-interaction.description: The serum concentration of the active metabolites of Folic acid can be reduced when Folic acid is used in combination with Glucarpidase resulting in a loss in efficacy.

drug-interaction.name: Leucovorin
drug-interaction.description: The serum concentration of the active metabolites of Leucovorin can be reduced when Leucovorin is used in combination with Glucarpidase resulting in a loss in efficacy.

drug-interaction.name: (6S)-5,6,7,8-tetrahydrofolic acid
drug-interaction.description: The serum concentration of the active metabolites of (6S)-5,6,7,8-tetrahydrofolic acid can be reduced when (6S)-5,6,7,8-tetrahydrofolic acid is used in combination with Glucarpidase resulting in a loss in efficacy.

drug-interaction.name: Triglu-5-formyl-tetrahydrofolate
drug-interaction.description: The serum concentration of the active metabolites of Triglu-5-formyl-tetrahydrofolate can be reduced when Triglu-5-formyl-tetrahydrofolate is used in combination with Glucarpidase resulting in a loss in efficacy.

drug-interaction.name: (6R)-Folinic acid
drug-interaction.description: The serum concentration of the active metabolites of (6R)-Folinic acid can be reduced when (6R)-Folinic acid is used in combination with Glucarpidase resulting in a loss in efficacy.

drug-interaction.name: 5-methyltetrahydrofolic acid
drug-interaction.description: The serum concentration of the active metabolites of 5-methyltetrahydrofolic acid can be reduced when 5-methyltetrahydrofolic acid is used in combination with Glucarpidase resulting in a loss in efficacy.

drug-interaction.name: Levomefolic acid
drug-interaction.description: The serum concentration of the active metabolites of Levomefolic acid can be reduced when Levomefolic acid is used in combination with Glucarpidase resulting in a loss in efficacy.

drug-interaction.name: Levoleucovorin
drug-interaction.description: The serum concentration of the active metabolites of Levoleucovorin can be reduced when Levoleucovorin is used in combination with Glucarpidase resulting in a loss in efficacy.

drug-interaction.name: Raltitrexed
drug-interaction.description: The metabolism of Raltitrexed can be increased when combined with Glucarpidase.

drug-interaction.name: Methotrexate
drug-interaction.description: The metabolism of Methotrexate can be increased when combined with Glucarpidase.

drug-interaction.name: Pemetrexed
drug-interaction.description: The metabolism of Pemetrexed can be increased when combined with Glucarpidase.

drug-interaction.name: Pralatrexate
drug-interaction.description: The metabolism of Pralatrexate can be increased when combined with Glucarpidase.

drug-interaction.name: Lometrexol
drug-interaction.description: The metabolism of Lometrexol can be increased when combined with Glucarpidase.

article.citation: Buchen S, Ngampolo D, Melton RG, Hasan C, Zoubek A, Henze G, Bode U, Fleischhack G: Carboxypeptidase G2 rescue in patients with methotrexate intoxication and renal failure. Br J Cancer. 2005 Feb 14;92(3):480-7.
Tuffaha HW, Al Omar S: Glucarpidase for the treatment of life-threatening methotrexate overdose. Drugs Today (Barc). 2012 Nov;48(11):705-11. doi: 10.1358/dot.2012.48.11.1871575.
Green JM: Glucarpidase to combat toxic levels of methotrexate in patients. Ther Clin Risk Manag. 2012;8:403-13. doi: 10.2147/TCRM.S30135. Epub 2012 Nov 22.
